questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with worsening fatigue, shortness of breath, and ankle swelling. His medical history includes joint pain, elevated liver enzymes, hyperpigmentation, and diabetes. He has recently been diagnosed with a metabolic disorder. An echocardiogram reveals elevated filling pressures and bilateral atrial enlargement. Which of the following best explains the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased contractility due to myocardial hypertrophy

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired diastolic filling due to stiffened ventricular walls

options.label: C
options.text: Dilated ventricular chambers leading to heart failure

options.label: D
options.text: Obstruction of blood flow through the left ventricle

questions.correct_answer: B. Impaired diastolic filling due to stiffened ventricular walls
questions.explanation:
Abnormal Diastolic Function
  • The primary abnormality in restrictive cardiomyopathy is impaired diastolic filling due to the stiffened ventricular walls.
  • Elevated end-diastolic pressures in both ventricles without significant chamber dilation.

Bilateral Atrial Enlargement

The non-compliant ventricles lead to increased pressures, resulting in dilation of both atria.

Right-Sided Heart Failure

The stiff ventricles result in increased filling pressures, particularly affecting the right side, causing peripheral oedema, ascites, and jugular venous distention.

Amyloid Infiltration (in amyloidosis)

Amyloid fibrils (pink hyaline deposits) accumulate between myocytes, leading to myocardial stiffening and restrictive physiology.

Cardiac amyloidosis (Congo red stain)

Fibrosis

In conditions like radiation-induced cardiomyopathy or endomyocardial fibrosis, stiffening of the myocardium occurs due to scarring, further impairing ventricular filling.

questions.text: Which of the following is a classic finding in cardiac tamponade?
questions.explanation:
Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad

  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other features

Pulsus Paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

Low-Pressure Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

This occurs when lower pericardial pressure leads to tamponade, often in cases of intravascular fluid depletion (e.g., hypovolemia).

Features

Jugular Venous Distension: Often absent

Pulsus Paradoxus: Rare

Requires a high degree of suspicion due to the absence of typical signs like jugular venous distension and pulsus paradoxus.

questions.text: A 60 y/o woman presents to the ED with severe shortness of breath and chest tightness. O/E, she is hypotensive with a blood pressure of 85/60 mmHg, has distended neck veins with a jugular venous pressure (JVP) of 12 cm H₂O, and her heart sounds are muffled. An echocardiogram shows the following: What is the most appropriate immediate and definitive treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Cardiac tamponade

Investigations

Treatment
  • Echocardiography: Primary diagnostic tool.
    • The diastolic collapse of the right ventricle.
    • Assesses pericardial effusion (size, location).
    • Normal E/A Ratio: In healthy individuals, the E/A ratio is typically greater than 1, indicating effective ventricular filling.
    • Diastolic Dysfunction: In cardiac tamponade, the E/A ratio can decrease to less than 1, signifying impaired diastolic filling and relaxation.
    • Shows respiratory variations in transvalvular flow velocities.
  • ECG:
    • Shows low QRS voltage due to fluid interference.
    • May present electrical alternans, indicating tamponade.
  • Right Heart Catheterization:
    • Provides haemodynamic data.
    • Reveals elevated and equalized pressures in all cardiac chambers during diastole.
  • Pericardiocentesis:
    • Immediate procedure to drain fluid and relieve pressure on the heart. (Option B)
    • Often guided by echocardiography.
  • Intravenous Saline: Given temporarily while getting ready for the procedure. (Option A ruled out)
  • Catheter Placement: A small catheter may be left in place post-pericardiocentesis for ongoing drainage if fluid reaccumulates.
  • Surgical Drainage (Subxiphoid Pericardiotomy): Indicated for recurrent tamponade, loculated effusions, or ineffective pericardiocentesis. (Option D ruled out)
  • Pericardial Fluid Analysis: Important for identifying the underlying cause of the effusion (e.g., cytology, cultures, PCR for infections).
  • Addressing Underlying Causes: Essential for preventing recurrence (e.g., antibiotics for infections, chemotherapy for malignancies).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, abdominal swelling, and peripheral oedema. On examination, he has elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP), hepatomegaly, and a loud third heart sound. There is also a rise in JVP during inspiration (see image below). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction

questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

Fatigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with signs of peripheral oedema and ascites. A chest X-ray reveals the following, and echocardiography confirms a thickened pericardium. Which of the following is the least accurate regarding his likely condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Conservative management with loop diuretics is curative

options.label: C
options.text: Commonly caused by tuberculosis in endemic regions

options.label: D
options.text: CT scan can assist in visualizing pericardial calcification

questions.correct_answer: A. Conservative management with loop diuretics is curative
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Purpose/Details

Chest X-ray

Detects pericardial calcification, a key diagnostic clue.

Echocardiography

Visualises thickened pericardium and assesses cardiac function.

CT scanning

Helps in visualising pericardial calcification.

Complex echo-Doppler and cardiac catheterisation

Used to differentiate constrictive pericarditis from restrictive cardiomyopathy when diagnosis is uncertain.

Management Type

Treatment

Purpose/Details

Medical Management

Diuretics (e.g., loop diuretics, spironolactone)

Helps manage diastolic heart failure by reducing fluid overload.

Surgical Management

Pericardiectomy

Definitive treatment through surgical removal of the diseased pericardium. Significant improvement is possible, but the procedure has high complication risk and suboptimal outcomes in up to 50% of patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old competitive athlete presents with recurrent syncope and exertional chest pain. He has a jerky, forceful pulse. ECG reveals left ventricular hypertrophy with deep Q waves in the inferolateral leads, and troponin T is mildly elevated. Echocardiography shows asymmetric septal hypertrophy, systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve, and a mid-systolic murmur at the heart's base. What is the most likely mechanism for his symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Diastolic heart failure due to a dilated left ventricle

questions.correct_answer: C. Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the ED after experiencing syncope while playing basketball. He has a palpable double impulse at the apex, and an ECG shows signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. An echocardiogram reveals asymmetric septal thickening with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Which of the following examination findings would NOT be expected in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Palpable double impulse at the apex

options.label: B
options.text: Late-peaking ejection systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border

options.label: C
options.text: Pulsus bisferiens on peripheral pulse examination

options.label: D
options.text: Prominent y descent in jugular venous pressure (JVP)

questions.correct_answer: D. Prominent y descent in jugular venous pressure (JVP)
questions.explanation:
Clinical Finding

Description

Palpable Left Ventricular Hypertrophy

An enlarged left ventricle can be felt during physical examination, indicating hypertrophy.

Double Impulse at the Apex

A palpable fourth heart sound suggests forceful atrial contraction against a non-compliant ventricle. (Option A ruled out)

Mid-Systolic Murmur at the Base

Turbulent blood flow through the obstructed left ventricular outflow tract produces a mid-systolic murmur.

Pansystolic Murmur at the Apex

Indicates mitral regurgitation caused by abnormal systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

Jerky Arterial Pulse

Characteristic of HOCM, contrasts with the slow-rising pulse seen in aortic stenosis.

Pulsus bisferiens (Option C ruled out)

A double pulse noticed during systole in the peripheral pulse is called pulsus bisferiens. It is associated with severe aortic disease accompanied by aortic regurgitation and HOCM.

Auscultatory Feature

Description

Clinical Relevance

Ejection Systolic Murmur(Option B ruled out)

Late-onset crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

Caused by turbulent blood flow through the obstructed LVOT; best heard at the left sternal border or apex.

Dynamic Changes with Maneuvers

Increased Intensity: Occurs with decreased preload (e.g., Valsalva manoeuvre, amyl nitrite).

Indicates worsening obstruction.

Decreased Intensity: Occurs with increased afterload (e.g., handgrip, inspiration).

Suggests improvement in outflow tract obstruction.

Non-Ejection Systolic Clicks

Clicks due to asymmetrical hypertrophy affecting the mitral chordae tendinae.

Indicates dynamic changes in the mitral apparatus, though less common.

Abnormal Second Heart Sound (S2)

May show delayed aortic closure with patterns of reverse splitting.

Correlates with the severity of left ventricular outflow obstruction; reversed or partially reversed splitting indicates severe obstruction.

questions.text: A 30 y/o male presents with exertional chest pain and occasional fainting spells. His family history includes a relative who experienced sudden cardiac death. An echocardiogram reveals asymmetric septal hypertrophy. Which of the following is not a characteristic investigatory finding in this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Deep, narrow Q waves in the lateral leads

options.label: C
options.text: Left ventricle free wall thickness >10 mm

questions.correct_answer: C. Left ventricle free wall thickness >10 mm

questions.text: A 35 y/o male presents with exertional dyspnea and palpitations during sports activities. His family history is significant for a relative who experienced sudden cardiac death at a young age. In managing this patient with suspected hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), which of the following is a first-line treatment option to relieve symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Medical Management
  • First-line Medications:
    • β-Adrenergic Blocking Agents (e.g., Metaprolol): Reduce heart rate and improve diastolic filling.
    • L-type Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil): Help decrease contractility and relieve outflow obstruction.
  • Additional Therapy for Persistent Symptoms:
    • Disopyramide: An antiarrhythmic agent with negative inotropic properties to control exertional dyspnea and chest pain.

Surgical and Procedural Options
  • Surgical Myectomy: Effective in relieving outflow tract obstruction by excising part of the septal myocardium.
  • Alcohol Septal Ablation: Suitable for patients with appropriate coronary anatomy; involves controlled infarction to relieve obstruction. Primarily for patients who prefer to avoid surgery or have comorbidities.

Indications
  • Recommended for patients with two or more risk factors for SCD.
  • Considered selectively for those with one risk factor.
  • Strongly indicated for patients who have previously survived cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation or sustained ventricular tachycardia.

High-Risk Features for Primary Prevention
  • Unexplained syncope
  • Abnormal blood pressure response during exercise
  • Significant ventricular hypertrophy (>30mm thickness)
  • Family history of SCD
  • Multiple episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female marathon runner collapses and is found unresponsive during a race. Despite attempts at resuscitation, she is pronounced dead at the scene. Her family reports a history of sudden cardiac death in her brother at a young age, and they mention that she had previously experienced episodes of dizziness and palpitations during training. Which of the following conditions is most likely to contribute to sudden cardiac death in this young athlete?
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors
  • Structural Heart Disease: The presence of structural heart issues or inherited arrhythmia syndromes significantly increases SCD risk.
  • Major Risk Factors:
    • Coronary Heart Disease (CHD)
    • Heart Failure
    • Diabetes
    • Hypertension
    • Smoking
    • Family History of SCD

Precipitating Factors
  • SCD and Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA) frequently occur at specific times (e.g., mornings, winter months) and in public places.
  • Vigorous exertion, especially in men, can trigger SCD; however, regular exercise may reduce this risk.

Underlying Heart Disease
  • The most common cause of SCD is Ventricular fibrillation
  • Many SCD cases are linked to coronary artery disease (CAD), but non-ischemic cardiomyopathies and other heart conditions also contribute.
  • Common mechanisms leading to SCD include:
    • Acute Myocardial Infarction
    • Bradyarrhythmias
    • Ventricular scars leading to arrhythmias

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath, fatigue, and mild chest discomfort. On examination, his blood pressure is low, and his heart sounds are faint on auscultation. The physician orders an echocardiogram, which shows the following Based on these findings, which of the following ECG patterns would you most likely expect to see?

A 60 y/o male with a history of amyloidosis presents with shortness of breath, fatigue, and leg swelling. He has jugular venous distension and ascites. An echocardiogram shows normal systolic function but diastolic dysfunction. The chest X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: B
options.text: Jugular venous pressure often shows rapid Y descents.

options.label: C
options.text: Atrial fibrillation is rare in these patients.

options.label: D
options.text: A third heart sound is more common than a fourth heart sound in sinus rhythm.

questions.correct_answer: B. Jugular venous pressure often shows rapid Y descents.
questions.explanation:
Amyloidosis

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Sarcoidosis

Bilateral Hair infiltrates

Hemochromatosis

Bronze skin, cirrhosis, Arthralgias

Endocrinopathies

Diabetes

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is being evaluated for restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM). Which of the following statements regarding the investigations and treatment options for RCM is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: An echocardiogram is the primary test for diagnosing RCM.

options.label: B
options.text: Low-to-normal QRS voltage on ECG can suggest amyloidosis.

options.label: C
options.text: Therapeutic phlebotomy is the primary treatment for sarcoidosis.

options.label: D
options.text: Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing cardiac amyloidosis.

questions.correct_answer: C. Therapeutic phlebotomy is the primary treatment for sarcoidosis.
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Treatment
  • ECG: Low-to-normal QRS voltage may suggest amyloidosis, but the absence of low voltage does not rule it out. (Option B ruled out)
  • Echocardiogram:
    • It is the primary test for RCM and helps differentiate it from conditions like constrictive pericarditis. (Option A ruled out)
    • Thickened walls of both ventricles without major chamber dilation.
    • The atria are markedly dilated, indicating chronically elevated ventricular filling pressures.
    • There is a characteristic hyperrefractile “glittering” appearance of the myocardium, typical of amyloid infiltration.

Granular sparkling heart

 
  • Cardiac Magnetic Resonance (CMR): Useful for diagnosing RCM and suggests amyloidosis through gadolinium enhancement.
  • Endomyocardial Biopsy (EMB): Gold standard for diagnosing cardiac amyloidosis; fat pad aspiration is also beneficial. (Option D ruled out)
  • Nuclear Imaging: Can show affinity for amyloid and aid in diagnosis.
  • Biomarkers: Troponin T, BNP, and pro-BNP are useful for diagnosis and prognosis.

Mutation Analysis: Used to diagnose hereditary hemochromatosis.
  • Treat Underlying Causes: Focus on alleviating symptoms and managing heart failure.
  • Diuretics: Mainstay for reducing volume overload; must be monitored to avoid excessive diuresis.
  • Beta-blockers/Calcium Channel Blockers: May be used to increase filling time and manage dysrhythmias.
  • Angiotensin-Receptor Blockers: Considered if systolic heart failure develops.
  • For Sarcoidosis: Antiarrhythmics and immunosuppressive agents like corticosteroids may be used.
  • For Hemochromatosis: Therapeutic phlebotomy is the treatment of choice. (Option C)
Advanced Treatments: Cardiac transplant or left ventricular assist devices may be options for some patients.

questions.text: A 55 y/o male presents to the emergency department with fatigue, shortness of breath, and swollen legs. Upon examination, his heart on imaging revealed the following, and his left ventricular ejection fraction is markedly reduced. Which of the following is NOT a recognised cause of this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Dilated Cardiomyopathy

Infective

  • Viral (coxsackievirus, adenovirus, HIV, hepatitis C)
  • Parasitic (Chagas’ disease, trypanosomiasis, toxoplasmosis) (Option B ruled out)
  • Bacterial (diphtheria)
  • Spirochetal (Lyme disease)
  • Rickettsial (Q fever)
  • Fungal (with systemic infection)

Noninfective

  • Granulomatous inflammatory disease
    • Sarcoidosis (Option A ruled out)
    • Giant cell myocarditis
    • Eosinophilic myocarditis
  • Polymyositis, dermatomyositis
  • Collagen vascular disease
  • Checkpoint inhibitor chemotherapy
  • Transplant rejection

Toxic

  • Alcohol
  • Catecholamines (amphetamines, cocaine)
  • Chemotherapeutic agents (anthracyclines, trastuzumab)
  • Interferon
  • Other therapeutic agents (hydroxychloroquine, chloroquine)
  • Drugs of misuse (emetine, anabolic steroids)
  • Heavy metals (lead, mercury) (Option D ruled out)
  • Occupational exposure (hydrocarbons, arsenicals)

Metabolic

  • Nutritional deficiencies (thiamine, selenium, carnitine)
  • Electrolyte deficiencies (calcium, phosphate, magnesium)
  • Endocrinopathy (thyroid disease, pheochromocytoma, diabetes, obesity, hemochromatosis)
  • Skeletal and cardiac myopathy
  • Dystrophin-related dystrophy (Duchenne’s, Becker’s)
  • Mitochondrial myopathies (e.g., Kearns-Sayre syndrome)

Overlap with Nondilated Cardiomyopathy

  • Minimally dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Amyloidosis
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (“burned-out”)
  • Idiopathic

Miscellaneous

  • Arrhythmogenic ventricular cardiomyopathy
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy
  • Left ventricular noncompaction
  • Tachycardia-related cardiomyopathy
  • Supraventricular arrhythmias with uncontrolled rate

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with increasing fatigue, shortness of breath during physical activity, and swelling in the legs. His mother reports that he has difficulty lying flat at night due to breathlessness. The child appears malnourished with signs of muscle wasting. On examination, there are crackles in the lung fields and elevated jugular venous pressure. An ECG reveals left ventricular enlargement. Which of the following findings is most consistent with the clinical features observed in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Left ventricular diastolic dimension ≥60 mm if chronic

options.label: C
options.text: Right ventricular dysfunction with no valvular regurgitation

options.label: D
options.text: Point of maximum impulse displaced medially

questions.correct_answer: B. Left ventricular diastolic dimension ≥60 mm if chronic

questions.text: A 50 y/o female with a history of heart failure presents with worsening fatigue, shortness of breath, and leg swelling. The Chest X-ray and Cardiac MRI of the patient are given below. Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of her condition is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral diuretics should be administered to maintain a euvolemic state.

options.label: B
options.text: ACE inhibitors are recommended for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

options.label: C
options.text: Beta-blockers should not be used in patients with symptomatic heart failure.

options.label: D
options.text: Isosorbide dinitrate plus hydralazine combination therapy may improve survival.

questions.correct_answer: C. Beta-blockers should not be used in patients with symptomatic heart failure.
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Treatment
  • Chest X-ray: May show cardiomegaly, pulmonary effusions, and venous congestion.
  • Electrocardiogram: Shows nonspecific ST segment and T wave abnormalities; can reveal atrial fibrillation.
  • Echocardiography: Can identify mural thrombus and differentiate from other cardiomyopathies.
  • Cardiac MRI.
  • Cardiac Catheterization with Coronary Angiography: Assesses coronary anatomy and rules out ischemic disease.
  • Heart Biopsy: Rarely needed; evaluates for storage diseases or infiltrative causes.
  • Genetic Testing: Considered in familial cases to identify hereditary factors.
  • Identify and Treat Reversible Causes: Address any underlying and reversible conditions contributing to DCM.
  • Acute Congestive Heart Failure: Use intravenous loop diuretics to manage hypervolemia. (Option A ruled out)
  • Chronic Management: Administer oral diuretics to maintain a euvolemic state.
  • Medical management:
    • ACE Inhibitors/ARBs(Option B ruled out)
    • Aldosterone Receptor Antagonists
    • Beta-Blockers
    • Combination Therapy: Isosorbide dinitrate plus hydralazine. (Option D ruled out)
  • Anticoagulation: Use in patients with artificial valves, atrial fibrillation, or known mural thrombus to reduce stroke risk.
  • Advanced Therapies: Consider cardiac transplantation or left ventricular assist devices (LVAD) for refractory cases.
  • ICD and CRT: Evaluate for implanted cardioverter defibrillators and cardiac resynchronization therapy for appropriate patients.
  • Heart Transplant: An option for severe cases, with indications including refractory cardiogenic shock and high inotrope dependency.

Chest X-Ray

Cardiac MRI

Gross Specimen

Cardiac Biopsy

questions.text: A post-mortem study reveals fibrinous deposits between the pericardial leaflets with a “bread and butter” appearance. Which of the following is most consistent with this form of pericarditis?
questions.explanation:
Types of Pericarditis

Fibrinous pericarditis
  • Often called "bread and butter" pericarditis due to fibrin deposits creating a rough appearance on the pericardium.
  • Caused by conditions like myocardial infarction, infections, trauma, or systemic diseases.
  • Associated with a granular, opaque pericardial surface from fibrin and leukocytic exudate.

Serous pericarditis
  • Characterized by clear fluid accumulation, often seen in viral infections or autoimmune diseases.
  • Less intense inflammation than fibrinous type.

Purulent pericarditis

(Option B ruled out)
  • Caused by bacterial infections, leading to a pus-filled pericardial sac.
  • Requires urgent treatment to prevent severe complications.

Haemorrhagic pericarditis

(Option A ruled out)
  • Involves blood within the pericardium, often due to trauma, malignancy, or uremia.
  • Common in cases with malignancies like lung or breast cancer.

Caseous pericarditis

(Option D ruled out)
  • Rare and typically associated with tuberculosis.
  • Has a cheese-like appearance due to necrotic tissue in the pericardium.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with sharp chest pain, fever, and pleuritis 3 weeks after undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism?
questions.correct_answer: B. Hypersensitivity reaction to myocardial antigens

questions.text: A 55 y/o woman presents with acute chest pain, difficulty breathing, and signs of heart failure following sudden emotional distress. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation without reciprocal depression, and echocardiography reveals ballooning of the left ventricular apex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart syndrome)

Yamaguchi Syndrome (Apical Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy)
  • Definition: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, or stress cardiomyopathy, is a transient condition characterized by left ventricular apical ballooning often triggered by emotional or physical stress, mimicking acute coronary syndrome without coronary obstruction.
  • Epidemiology: Predominantly affects postmenopausal women, triggered by emotional or physical stress.
  • Clinical Presentation: Chest pain, signs of acute heart failure, resembling acute coronary syndrome.
  • ECG: ST-segment elevation, absent reciprocal depression, T-wave inversion, mild QT prolongation.
  • Biochemistry: Elevated catecholamines, BNP, and modest troponin rise.
  • Imaging:
    • Echocardiography: Classic "takotsubo" ballooning of the left ventricular apex, with basal segments hyperdynamic and apex hypokinetic. Can show left ventricular outflow tract obstruction or mitral regurgitation.
    • MRI: Apical ballooning with high T2 intensity (oedema), typically sparing the basal segments. No late enhancement, differentiating it from anterior STEMI.
    • Left Ventriculography: Demonstrates transient dysfunction and ballooning of mid and apical segments of the left ventricle.
  • Prognosis: Excellent recovery with supportive treatment, typically resolves in weeks to months.
  • Definition: A rare form of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy affecting the left ventricle's apex, occasionally the right or both.
  • Epidemiology: More common in Japanese populations (15-25% of HCM cases) compared to the U.S. (~3%).
  • Symptoms: Often asymptomatic; possible symptoms include chest pain, palpitations, dyspnea, and syncope.
  • ECG Findings: Left ventricular hypertrophy with deep negative T waves, especially in leads V4-V5.
  • Pathology: Usually sporadic, with occasional autosomal dominant inheritance.

Imaging: "Ace-of-spades" or "spade-like" left ventricle configuration on imaging

questions.text: A 12 y/o girl presents with a recent onset of involuntary, jerky movements in her hands and face, worsening with stress or purposeful tasks. Her mother recalls multiple untreated sore throats months ago. O/E, she has irregular, rapid, non-rhythmic hand movements, difficulty with facial control, and trouble sustaining muscle contraction. Her motor function is otherwise normal. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Category

Medications

Purpose

Initial Antibiotic Prophylaxis

Benzathine penicillin G

Prevent the recurrence of rheumatic fever

Additional Treatment

Neuroleptics: Pimozide, haloperidol, risperidone, olanzapine (Option B ruled out)

Control chorea symptoms

Anticonvulsants: Valproate, carbamazepine (Option D ruled out)

Off-label use for symptom management

Immunomodulatory Therapy

Corticosteroids, Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), Plasma exchange (Option C ruled out)

For severe/persistent symptoms

Monitoring

Gradual tapering after 1 month of symptom-free

Reduce side effects

questions.text: A 35 y/o male presents to the ED after experiencing a brief episode of syncope. He reports occasional palpitations and dizziness. His family history is significant for sudden cardiac deaths at a young age. An ECG of leads V1-V3 is given below. Which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient, given the findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe a beta-blocker and advise lifestyle modifications

options.label: B
options.text: Perform a drug challenge test with procainamide

options.label: C
options.text: Refer for genetic testing for SCN5A mutations

questions.explanation:
Brugada Syndrome

About

A rare, inherited disease that predisposes patients to potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias, characterised by right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevations in the right precordial leads (V1-V3) on ECG.

Clinical features
  • Symptoms range from asymptomatic to sudden cardiac death, often during sleep.
  • Syncope in 80% of patients with ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
  • Other symptoms: palpitations, dizziness, and fever history may trigger symptoms.

ECG findings
  • Type I: Coved ST elevations >2 mm with inverted T wave.
  • Type II: Saddleback-shaped ST elevation >2 mm.
  • Type III: Saddleback-shaped ST elevations <2 mm.
  • Patients with a normal ECG and high-risk factors may need a drug challenge test to reveal ST elevations in leads V1 to V3. 

Drug challenge test
  • Drugs used in the challenge test:
    • Class IA antiarrhythmics (procainamide, ajmaline).
    • IC antiarrhythmics (flecainide, propafenone).
  • Brugada ECG findings can also emerge from cocaine use or tricyclic antidepressant toxicity.
  • Electrolyte abnormalities like hyperkalemia and hypercalcemia can reveal ST elevations in the right precordial leads.
  • A normal drug challenge test in pediatric patients may need to be repeated after puberty due to hormonal influences.
  • The "full stomach test" can also help expose ST elevations by increasing vagal tone.
  • Additional diagnostic options include genetic testing for SCN5A mutations and invasive electrophysiology.

Treatment
  • Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) for high-risk patients.

questions.text: A 55 y/o male presents to the ED with severe chest pain radiating to his left arm. His ECG is given below. Based on this information, which of the following changes is most likely present in this ECG?

A 16 y/o boy with a history of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) without carditis presents for follow-up. He has been on benzathine penicillin G for four years. Based on the AHA guidelines, what is the recommended duration for continuing secondary prophylaxis in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Continue prophylaxis until the age of 25

options.label: D
options.text: Continue prophylaxis until the age of 21

questions.correct_answer: D. Continue prophylaxis until the age of 21
questions.explanation:
Secondary Prevention in Acute Rheumatic Fever

Preferred Antibiotic

Benzathine penicillin G is recommended as the first choice. Dosage is:

  • 1.2 million units for individuals >27 kg.
  • 600,000 units for individuals ≤27 kg.

Typically administered every 4 weeks, may increase to every 2–3 weeks for adherence issues.

Alternative Antibiotics

Oral Erythromycin (250 mg twice daily) is recommended for patients allergic to penicillin.

Oral penicillin V (250 mg twice daily) can be used but is less effective.

Duration of Prophylaxis

Determined by the presence and severity of carditis, age, and time since the last ARF episode

No Carditis

(Option B)

5 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer.

Carditis without Valvular Disease

10 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer.

Persistent Valvular Disease

10 years or until 40 years of age, whichever is longer.

Lifelong prophylaxis may be needed in severe cases.

questions.text: A 10 y/o boy presents with fever, joint pain, and a recent history of sore throat. Examination reveals a heart murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. Laboratory tests show elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct invasion of heart valves by Streptococcus bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: Immune response triggered by molecular mimicry between bacterial antigens and heart tissue

options.label: C
options.text: Autoimmune destruction of heart valves due to viral infection

options.label: D
options.text: Genetic mutations in heart muscle proteins

questions.correct_answer: B. Immune response triggered by molecular mimicry between bacterial antigens and heart tissue

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is most commonly associated with Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF) in the Indian population?
questions.explanation:
The course of Acute Rheumatic Fever

Latent Period

Common Early Features

Late Features
  • After upper respiratory tract infection/ pharyngitis with GABHS, ARF symptoms typically develop after a latent period of 3 weeks (range: 1–5 weeks).
  • A sore throat can occur.
  • Chorea and indolent carditis can manifest up to 6 months later following a prolonged latent period.
  • Polyarthritis: Seen in 60-75% of ARF cases, often affecting large joints (knees, ankles, elbows). Migratory inflammation is a key feature.
  • Carditis: Occurs in 50-75% of cases, frequently leading to mitral valve damage (regurgitation initially). Aortic valve involvement is also common..
  • Valvular damage can progress from regurgitation to stenosis over time, leading to heart failure in the long term.
  • Recurrent ARF episodes increase the risk of chronic heart valve disease (rheumatic heart disease).
  • Chorea: Varies by population, from less than 2% to 30%. Predominantly affects females and often coexists with carditis.
  • Skin Manifestations: Erythema marginatum (rare, less than 5% of cases) and subcutaneous nodules (also less than 5%). (Options B and C ruled out)

questions.text: A 10 y/o boy presents with fever, joint pain, and a new onset heart murmur. On auscultation, a soft mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the apex. Echocardiography reveals mitral valve inflammation. Which of the following murmurs is most likely present in this patient?
Which statements describe the relationship between Sydenham's chorea and acute rheumatic fever?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an early manifestation of rheumatic fever

options.label: B
options.text: It occurs in all patients with rheumatic fever

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with emotional lability

options.label: D
options.text: It has no connection to previous infections

questions.correct_answer: C. It is associated with emotional lability

questions.text: Based on the 2015 Modified Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Fever, which of the following is NOT part of the major criteria for a low-risk population?
questions.explanation:
Criteria

Low-Risk Population

High-Risk Population

Major Criteria
  • Carditis (clinical or subclinical) (Option A ruled out)
  • Polyarthritis (Option B ruled out)
  • Chorea (Option C ruled out)
  • Erythema marginatum
  • Subcutaneous nodules
  • Carditis (clinical or subclinical)
  • Monoarthritis or Polyarthritis
  • Chorea
  • Erythema marginatum
  • Subcutaneous nodules
  • Polyarthralgia (Option D)

Minor Criteria
  • Polyarthralgia (Option D)
  • Hyperpyrexia (≥ 38.5ºC)
  • ESR ≥ 60 mm/h and/or CRP ≥ 3.0 mg/dl
  • Prolonged PR interval (if no there is no carditis in major criterion)
  • Monoarthralgia
  • Hyperpyrexia (≥ 38.0ºC)
  • ESR ≥ 30 mm/h and/or CRP ≥ 3.0 mg/dl
  • Prolonged PR interval (if no there is no carditis in major criterion)

questions.text: A 25 y/o woman presents with h/o exertional dyspnea, palpitations, and episodes of syncope. She recalls experiencing multiple episodes of sore throat as a child, followed by joint pains, for which she received no definitive treatment. On auscultation, there is a diastolic murmur at the apex and a loud S1. She has heart rate of 75-80 bpm. An echocardiogram reveals significant mitral stenosis with left atrial enlargement. What is the next most appropriate step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: ACE Inhibitors and rate control drugs

questions.explanation:
Condition

Medical Management

Interventional/Surgical Options

Mitral Stenosis
  • Anticoagulation to prevent embolism.
  • Rate control (e.g., digoxin, beta-blockers, calcium antagonists) in AF.(Option C ruled out)
  • Diuretics for pulmonary congestion.
  • Balloon valvuloplasty.
  • Mitral valvotomy.
  • Mitral valve replacement.

Mitral Regurgitation
  • Diuretics and vasodilators for symptom relief.
  • Digoxin and anticoagulants in AF.
  • ACE inhibitors/ARBs for hypertension. (Option C ruled out)
  • Mitral valve repair (preferred). (Option B ruled out)
  • Mitral valve replacement (if repair is not feasible).

Aortic Stenosis

Not applicable

Aortic valve replacement (for severe stenosis with symptoms like angina, syncope, or heart failure).

Aortic Regurgitation

Not applicable

Aortic valve replacement (indicated for symptomatic cases, sometimes combined with aortic root replacement or coronary bypass).

Therapy

Details

Medical Therapy

Medications to improve cardiac function, reduce fluid overload, and control blood pressure. Eg. Diuretics, ACE inhibitors and ARBs

Device Therapy

ICD (Implantable cardiac defibrillators): For preventing sudden cardiac death due to ventricular arrhythmias.

CRT (Cardiac resynchronisation therapy): For improving heart function in heart failure with conduction abnormalities (e.g., left bundle branch block).

Prevention Strategy

Details

Long-Term Antibiotic Prophylaxis

Prevents recurrent attacks of rheumatic fever.

Antibiotic Prophylaxis for Procedures

May be necessary before dental or surgical procedures to reduce the risk of infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A 68 y/o postmenopausal woman presents to the emergency department with chest pain and dyspnea after a recent stressful event. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation and cardiac biomarkers are mildly elevated. After a thorough evaluation, she is diagnosed with a condition resembling acute coronary syndrome. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Perform immediate coronary angiography and start aspirin.

questions.correct_answer: D. Perform immediate coronary angiography and start aspirin.
questions.explanation:
Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy

Investigations
  • ECG Changes: Similar to pericarditis stages, with ST-segment elevation, T-wave inversions, and eventual normalization.
  • Cardiac Biomarkers: Mild elevation of troponins (median initial troponin: 7.7 times normal) and elevated BNP or N-terminal pro-BNP levels.
  • Echocardiography: Systolic apical ballooning of LV with mid-apical depression.
  • Cardiovascular Magnetic Resonance (CMR): Helps diagnose stress cardiomyopathy, showing myocardial oedema, necrosis, and fibrosis.

Treatment
  • Risk Factors for Adverse Outcomes: Physical triggers, neurologic/psychiatric conditions, high initial troponin, low ejection fraction, male gender.
  • Initial Treatment: Aspirin, beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, lipid-lowering agents, and coronary angiography.
  • Stable Patients:
    • Cardioselective beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors for 3-6 months.
    • Serial imaging to monitor wall motion and ejection fraction.
  • Anticoagulation: Reserved for patients with ventricular thrombus (5% occurrence). (Option A ruled out)
  • Unstable Patients: Inotropes for cardiogenic shock without left ventricular outflow obstruction. (Option C ruled out)
  • Mechanical support (intra-aortic balloon pump or left ventricular assist devices) may be needed.
  • If Outflow Obstruction Present: Avoid inotropes; phenylephrine is the preferred pressor, often combined with beta-blockers.

Echocardiogram showing "apical ballooning" pattern

Left ventriculography during systole showing apical ballooning akinesis with basal hyperkinesis in a characteristic Takotsubo ventricle.

questions.text: A 72 y/o female with a history of mitral valve prolapse presents with a low-grade fever, night sweats, and fatigue persisting for over a month. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur and petechiae on her extremities. Blood cultures are sent. What is the leading organism associated with this patient's probable condition?
questions.explanation:
Acute Bacterial Endocarditis

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis (SBE)
  • Aggressive course compared to subacute endocarditis.
  • Causative organisms: S. aureus (Most common cause) (including MRSA), S. pneumoniae, L. monocytogenes, Haemophilus species, streptococci (groups A, B, G).
  • Risk factors: Comorbid conditions like malignancy, diabetes mellitus, IV drug use, or alcoholism.
  • Presentation:
    • Fever, fatigue, and malaise within <2 weeks of infection.
    • Changing heart murmur, potential congestive heart failure.
    • Possible signs: Janeway lesions (hemorrhagic macules on palms/soles), petechiae, Roth’s spots, splinter haemorrhages, splenomegaly (rare).
  • Slow progression compared to Acute endocarditis
  • Causative organism: Streptococcus viridans (Most common cause)
  • Presentation:
    • Gradual onset over weeks to months (>2 weeks) but can be life-threatening if untreated.
    • Symptoms: unexplained fever, chills, night sweats, fatigue, weight loss, joint/muscle aches, chest/back pain, and skin rashes.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Periodontal disease, IV drug use, prolonged IV medication.
    • Congenital heart defects, prior endocarditis, valve surgery, or pacemaker implants.
    • More common in men, especially over age 60.
  • Treatment:
    • High-dose IV antibiotics for 2-6 weeks.
    • Surgery may be needed for abscess drainage or valve repair/replacement.

questions.text: A 68 y/o male with a prosthetic valve presents with fever, night sweats, and fatigue 6 months post-surgery. Blood cultures are negative, and he was exposed to a contaminated heater-cooler device during valve replacement. Which organism is most likely responsible for his prosthetic valve endocarditis?
In the context of infective endocarditis, what role do MSCRAMMs play in the disease process?

options.label: A
options.text: They enhance the immune response against pathogens during bacteremia.

options.label: B
options.text: They facilitate bacterial adherence to nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) or injured endothelium.

options.label: C
options.text: They are responsible for the formation of emboli that lead to tissue infarction.

options.label: D
options.text: They promote the breakdown of vegetation formed in the heart.

questions.correct_answer: B. They facilitate bacterial adherence to nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) or injured endothelium.

questions.text: A 60 y/o man with a mechanical aortic valve presents with 2 weeks of fever, fatigue, and shortness of breath. He has a history of a dental procedure done 3 weeks back. Blood cultures are negative. FDG-PET/CT shows abnormal uptake around the valve. Which major criterion from the Modified Duke’s Criteria does this patient meet?

options.label: A
options.text: Negative blood culture for a typical organism

options.label: B
options.text: Evidence of endocardial involvement by FDG-PET/CT

questions.correct_answer: B. Evidence of endocardial involvement by FDG-PET/CT
questions.explanation:
Modified Duke’s Criteria - Major criteria

Positive blood cultures
  • Identification of a typical organism from two cultures, or persistent positive cultures drawn more than 12 hours apart.
  • Three or more positive cultures that have been taken over at least one hour apart.
  • A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or a phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800.

Evidence of endocardial involvement
  • Positive echocardiographic findings such as vegetations, abscesses, or new valvular regurgitation.
  • Oscillating intracardiac masses or partial dehiscence of a prosthetic valve.
  • Additional diagnostic tools like FDG-PET/CT or EKG-gated cardiac CT angiograms also meet major criteria for prosthetic valve endocarditis. (Added by the European Society of Cardiology)

questions.text: Which of the following is a minor criterion under the Modified Duke’s Criteria for infective endocarditis?

options.label: B
options.text: Two positive blood cultures with a typical organism

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of a prosthetic valve
questions.explanation:
Modified Duke’s Criteria - Minor criteria

Predisposing heart condition

Any pre-existing valvular or cardiac abnormality, such as valvular disease, congenital heart defects, or prosthetic valves. (Option C)

Intravenous drug use

Recognised as a significant risk factor for IE.

Fever ≥ 38°C

Commonly seen in patients with IE.

Vascular phenomena

Such as embolic events (stroke, septic pulmonary infarcts), mycotic aneurysms, intracranial haemorrhages and Janeway lesions.

Immunological phenomena

Rheumatoid factor, Osler’s nodes, Roth's spots or glomerulonephritis.

Positive blood culture not meeting major criteria

Isolation of organisms typical of IE in a single culture or other non-major findings.

Suggestive echocardiography

Abnormal findings that raise suspicion but do not meet the criteria for a major criterion. (D529)

questions.text: A 72 y/o man presents with fever and night sweats. Blood cultures are repeatedly negative, but PCR testing from a sterile joint aspirate identifies Staphylococcus aureus. Echocardiography reveals mitral regurgitation. Based on the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria, which of the following is a minor criterion for diagnosing infective endocarditis?

options.label: C
options.text: PCR from a sterile body site identifying a typical pathogen

questions.correct_answer: C. PCR from a sterile body site identifying a typical pathogen
questions.explanation:
The 2023 Duke-International Society for Cardiovascular Infectious Diseases (ISCVID) Criteria for Infective Endocarditis - Minor Criteria Updates

Predisposing Conditions

Expanded to include transcatheter valve procedures, endovascular leads of cardiac implantable devices, and a history of IE.

Vascular Phenomenon

Includes splenic and cerebral abscesses.

Immunological Phenomena

Clarifies immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, with a practical definition involving unexplained acute kidney injury, hematuria, proteinuria, or a renal biopsy showing immune complex disease.

Microbiological Evidence

PCR, amplicon or metagenomic sequencing of typical pathogens from sterile sites other than cardiac tissue is now a minor criterion. (Option C)

Imaging

Abnormal metabolic activity detected by [18F]FDG PET/CT within three months of prosthetic valve or device implantation is included.

Physical Exam

A new regurgitant murmur on auscultation is considered a minor criterion when echocardiography is unavailable.

questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents with sharp, pleuritic chest pain worsened by lying down and relieved by sitting up. He had a recent viral illness. A friction rub is heard on auscultation, and ECG shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Acute Pericarditis

Aetiology

Clinical Features

Infectious causes

Noninfectious causes
  • Viruses: Coxsackievirus, echovirus, herpes viruses.
  • Bacteria: Streptococcus, Staphylococcus, tuberculosis.
  • Fungal infections: Histoplasmosis.
  • Other infections: Syphilis, protozoal, and parasitic infections.
  • Renal failure
  • Neoplasms
  • Trauma
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction, post-irradiation, metabolic disorders (myxedema, cholesterol pericarditis).
  • Drug-induced: Medications like procainamide, and hydralazine.
  • Post-cardiac injury syndrome: Autoimmune reaction after surgery, trauma.
  • Autoimmune diseases: Lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma.
  • Idiopathic.
  • Chest pain

Sharp, pleuritic pain, worsened by lying down, relieved by sitting up. Radiates to trapezius, may mimic myocardial ischemia.

  • Pericardial friction rub

Rasping and scratching sounds are heard in the majority of patients. It is best heard during end-expiration with the patient leaning forward.

  • Pericardial effusion:

It can lead to cardiac tamponade if rapid. Faint heart sounds, and a large cardiac silhouette on X-ray.

Ewart’s sign: Dullness and egophony below the left scapula due to compression of the base of the lungs

  • ECG changes:

Diffuse concave upward ST-segment elevation, PR-segment depression.

Evolves through stages: ST elevation → return to baseline → T-wave inversion → normalisation.

PR segment depression in MI patients is seen due to concomitant atrial injury.

questions.text: A 60 y/o male with acute pericarditis who has not responded to NSAIDs and colchicine is now experiencing frequent recurrences. He does not tolerate glucocorticoids well. What additional treatment can be considered?

options.label: C
options.text: Begin a higher dose of colchicine

questions.explanation:
Acute Pericarditis

Investigations

Treatment
  • Echocardiography:
    • The primary tool for diagnosing pericardial fluid.
    • Significant pericardial effusion can be identified if fluid exceeds 1 cm.
  • CT & MRI:
    • Detect loculated effusions, masses, or inflammation (MRI)
    • Used to confirm pericardial effusion or thickening.
    • MRI also assesses fibrosis and constrictive pericarditis.

Conservative Management:

Rest and anti-inflammatory drugs for idiopathic pericarditis.

  • Aspirin/NSAIDs:
    • Doses: Aspirin (2-4 g/day) or ibuprofen/indomethacin with gastric protection.
    • Continue for 1-2 weeks, and taper over time.
  • Colchicine:
    • Dose: 0.5 mg daily (<70 kg) or twice daily (>70 kg) for 3 months.
    • Reduces recurrence risk but may cause diarrhoea.
  • Glucocorticoids:
    • Only for NSAID/colchicine-resistant cases, short-term use (2-4 days), then tapered.
    • Prolonged use raises the recurrence risk.
  • Immunosuppressants: Azathioprine or anakinra in cases of frequent recurrence is unresponsive to other treatments.
  • Avoid Anticoagulants: Risk of bleeding into the pericardial cavity, leading to tamponade.

Surgical: Pericardial stripping for rare, severe cases with recurrent effusion.
